para.paratext: This standard document service level agreement is to be used where the services in question are maintenance and support of specified software. It provides for service credits if actual supplier performance fails to meet the performance standards set in the service levels. It is presented in the form of a schedule, but can be readily adapted to comprise a free-standing agreement if needed.

Service levels and service credits are tools used to ensure that the supplier performs the services to the required standard. They define how well the supplier needs to perform and the immediate financial consequences of failure. Service credits are a mechanism by which amounts are deducted from the amounts to be paid under the contract to the supplier if actual supplier performance fails to meet the performance standards set in the service levels. The main agreement may contain various other mechanisms to rectify poor service delivery. For more information, see Practice note, Service levels and service credit schemes in outsourcing. This note analyses how service levels may be set and used and the service credit schemes that may be employed to encourage good performance. The context is outsourcing transactions, but many of the principles referred to in the note are generally applicable.

In this standard document, the services in question are maintenance and support of specified on-premises software. It is assumed that, where cloud services are involved, support and maintenance may be conducted centrally by the cloud provider, so some of the provisions of this schedule may not be relevant (for example, it may not be possible to roll back to a previous version or release of the software, see Drafting note, Exclusive or non-exclusive remedy). For more on cloud support, see Practice note, Cloud services: hybrid cloud and outsourcing: Support.

Typically, software support SLAs are only drafted to deal with response and resolve times for operational defects which affect the functions of the software, and do not deal with wider security aspects (such as addressing security vulnerabilities that may be present in software).

In light of the increased prevalence, severity, and media scrutiny given to, cybersecurity attacks and the changing regulatory landscape in this area (see Practice note, UK cybersecurity law and Drafting note, Network and Information Systems Regulations 2018) we have included some optional clauses in this standard document to widen the definition of Fault to also cover security vulnerabilities. However, this is approach is largely untested in the legal market and so may be pushed back against by software support vendors who may argue that it would be extremely difficult to set specific service levels relating to security, or may have their own standardised procedures already set up for this. The optional wording is therefore included to ensure that the security aspects of software support are not overlooked, and it may be that the parties will need to build upon these provisions (should it wish to address software security as well as remedying functional defects) to fit with what is technically achievable in practice.

Alternatively, the parties may wish to draft and negotiate an entirely separate security level agreement to fit alongside a typical service level agreement for support services, to cover a broader spectrum of cybersecurity risks in addition to software vulnerabilities.

head.headtext: Supply chain issues: slavery and human trafficking

para.paratext: The Modern Slavery Act 2015 (MSA) is aimed at combating crimes of slavery and human trafficking. Section 54 of the MSA requires commercial organisations having a global turnover of £36 million or more to publish an annual slavery and human trafficking statement for each financial year that ends on or after 31 March 2016. The statement must disclose what steps the organisation has taken to ensure that human trafficking is not taking place in any of its supply chains or its business; or state that it has taken no such steps. A customer may want to include wording in its supply agreements that have a connection with a supply chain to prohibit the use of forced or trafficked labour.
For further information on the MSA including links to example clauses, see Modern Slavery Act 2015 toolkit.

The Network and Information Systems Regulations 2018 came into effect on 10 May 2018 pursuant to the Cybersecurity Directive ((EU)2016/1148) (also known as the Network and Information Security or NIS Directive). They have potential impact on any operator of essential services (OES) that relies on IT systems in the following sectors: energy, transport, health, drinking water supply and distribution, digital infrastructure; and on relevant providers of online marketplaces, online search engines and cloud computing services (Relevant Digital Service Providers (RDSPs)). Like the General Data Protection Regulation ((EU) 2016/679), the NIS Regulations impose security and incident reporting requirements and provide for high penalties (up to £17 million in the case of the NIS Regulations), but their focus is on security of IT systems, rather than security of the personal data processed by those systems; in practice the two regimes are inextricably linked.

For a definition of an OES see Practice note, Cybersecurity Directive: UK implementation: Identification or Designation as an OES, and for a definition of an RDSP see Practice note, Cybersecurity Directive: UK implementation: Identification as an RDSP.

OESs and RDSPs have obligations to maintain the security of the systems on which their services rely and to report security incidents to their respective regulators (the ICO is the regulator for RDSPs and Schedule 1 of the NIS Regulations lists the regulators for OES). If the customer is an OES or a RDSP, it may require its software support vendors to help it maintain the security of its software, as well as its functional output.
For more information on regulation in this area, see Practice note, Cybersecurity Directive: UK implementation.

On 31 January 2020 (exit day), the UK left the EU and the UK-EU withdrawal agreement entered into force. For general information on the withdrawal agreement, future relationship agreements, and the operation of UK law following the end of the transition period, see UK legal change post-transition and UK-EU agreements toolkit, Retained EU law toolkit and Practical Law's Brexit page.

The CJEU continues to have some relevance in UK law on an ongoing basis, although CJEU principles and decisions made since the end of the transition period are not binding on UK courts or tribunals; see Practice note, EU law in the UK after Brexit: Approach to EU law by UK courts.

Section 2 to section 4 of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018 (EUWA) created a category of law called "retained EU law" at the end of the transition period. Retained EU law includes EU-derived domestic legislation, some (formerly) directly applicable EU legislation and some other EU rights that were recognised and available in UK law. For more information see Practice note, Retained EU law and assimilated law FAQs: What is retained EU law?

The Retained EU Law (Revocation and Reform) Act 2023 (REUL Act) makes provision for significant changes to the status, operation and content of retained EU law and most of its provisions come into force at the end of 2023. Retained EU law is known as assimilated law for matters arising after the end of 2023, but is referred to in this resource as retained EU law for consistency.

The UK government has published a list of retained EU law relating to intellectual property which contains a number of pieces of EU-derived primary and secondary legislation (see Legal update, Government guidance on IP and retained EU law updated).
For more information about retained EU-derived domestic legislation, see Practice note, Retained EU law and assimilated law FAQs: EU-derived domestic legislation.

Retained EU case law is a defined body of case law that is used to interpret retained EU law. Broadly speaking, it consists of the principles laid down by, and any decisions of, the CJEU as they had effect in EU law immediately before the end of the transition period.

Section 6 of the REUL Act is to come into force on a date specified by commencement regulations, and includes provisions designed to encourage the courts to depart from retained EU case law when interpreting retained EU law. For more information, see Practice note, Retained EU Law (Revocation and Reform) Act 2023: Interpretation and effect of retained EU law.

head.headtext: Response times for mitigation of security vulnerabilities (optional)

para.paratext: We have expanded the typical service level responses to cover the mitigation of security vulnerabilities, should the parties wish to include this. However, this will likely require adaptation in light of what is technically achievable in practice, see Drafting note, About this document.
The parties may, on a case-by-case basis, agree in writing to a reasonable extension of the Service Level response times.

The Supplier shall give the Customer regular updates of the nature and status of its efforts to correct [(or, where, relevant, Mitigate)] any Fault [and monthly reports as to achievement of Service Levels and Service Credits to which the Customer has become entitled].
If acting for the Customer, select the optional text and consider requiring the updates to specify a description of the problem and the estimated time of resolution.

If the Supplier fails to provide a Solution within the relevant Service Level response time, the Customer shall become entitled to the Service Credit specified in the table set out below corresponding to the relevant severity level of Fault on submitting a written claim for such Service Credit, provided that the relevant Fault or other problem relating to the Software:
did not result from a Customer Cause or a cause outside the Supplier's control; and
[save in the case of Vulnerabilities which should have been detected under paragraph 2.2(f),] was promptly notified to the Supplier under paragraph 4.3(a).

In this document the Service Credit amounts are determined by applying a specified percentage figure to the annual support fee and multiplying the result by the number of relevant days. Alternative approaches include specifying a fixed amount and multiplying the result by the number of relevant days.
The parties acknowledge that each Service Credit is proportionate when considering the Customer's legitimate interest to address and resolve all Faults as quickly as possible.

When agreeing a service credit regime, the parties should consider the legal implications that arise through use of service credits, including their enforceability. For further discussion on this topic, see Practice note, Contracts: agreed remedies: The rule against penalties.
The provision of a Service Credit shall be an exclusive remedy for a particular Service Level failure.
If acting for the Customer, consider deleting paragraph 6.3 and adding the following additional remedy:

"Without limiting the Supplier's obligation under paragraph 6.1, if the then-current Software exhibits a severity level 1 or severity level 2 Fault that is unresolved, the Customer may, at its option, use any previous version or release of the Software in which a severity level 1 or severity level 2 Fault does not occur or can be worked around, and the Supplier shall perform all Support Services for such version or release until the Supplier provides a Solution."
Also consider whether the Service Credits are intended to be the sole remedy for Service Level failures and, if not, consider adding the following provisions:

"Even if the Customer becomes entitled to a Service Credit under this schedule, the Customer may obtain such other remedies as may be available to it, either under the Main Agreement or otherwise at law or in equity, including the right to terminate the Main Agreement in accordance with clause [NUMBER]. If the Customer exercises such right then, without prejudice to any other rights and remedies that may be available to it, any further Support Fees that fall due during the relevant termination notice period shall remain payable, but the Customer shall cease to be liable for any Support Fees falling due after the notice period has expired. The Supplier shall provide a pro-rata refund of any Support Fees paid in advance."
Failure to meet the [SERVICE LEVEL TYPE] Service Level [FREQUENCY OF FAILURE IN RELEVANT TIMEFRAME] shall be deemed a [material breach OR breach of a material clause] under clause [NUMBER]."

The aim of the second provision is to facilitate termination by the Customer if the specified Service Levels are not met. Insert the number of the termination clause. The appropriate Service Level should be specified (if there is more than one) and reference to the appropriate clause should be included. If you wish to restrict the operation of this paragraph to multiple failures to meet the relevant service level, you can do so by inserting appropriate text in the second set of square brackets, for example, "twice in any 12-month period".

The parties might seek to achieve a compromise by identifying the particular Service Level failures for which provision of a Service Credit shall or shall not be an exclusive remedy. This may depend, for example, on the severity level of the relevant Fault or other problem relating to the Software.

The supplier should be aware that any attempt by it to make service credits an exclusive remedy may be subject to the reasonableness test under the Unfair Contract Terms Act 1977 (see, Practice note, Issues in IT contracts litigation: Service credits as the customer's exclusive remedy).

Service Credits shall be shown as a deduction from the amount due from the Customer to the Supplier in the next invoice then due to be issued under the Main Agreement. The Supplier shall not in any circumstances be obliged to pay any money or make any refund to the Customer.
